page.title: 05Widmerpool Hall (1)
page.content: The present hall has no direct conn- ection with the ancient Saxon family of Wimarspol or Wide mere Polle, but was built in 1872-73 on a slight ridge as a private residence for the lord of the manor of Widmerpool estate, compr- ising about 890 hectares of land. The previous hall was demolished in 1875. The Hall is built in modern Gothic style in the form of a parallelogram, of Bath and Clipsham limestone, with a lofty and handsome clock tower but at present no clock. The grounds were planted with a wide variety of trees including the American Coast redwood, yews and, in the nearby churchyard, cedars of Lebanon (among Britain's earliest). Parts of the grounds are now used for private houses but many trees remain. Wild birds find homes in the trees and underbrush and over 40 species of birds have been identified.
